field_edited_text.value:
56 Paraprsco River CROSSING

Baltimore Association of Commerce recommended the following harbor
improvements:—

a. The widening of the channel from Sandy Point to Fort McHenry

from 600 feet to 1000 feet.

b. The widening of the Port Covington channel from 400 feet to 600 feet.

c¢. The widening of the Curtis Bay channel from 400 feet to 600 feet.

The following deepening was also recommended :—

a. The deepening of the main channel from Sandy Point to Sparrows

Point from 37 feet to 40 feet.

b. From Sparrows Point to Fort McHenry from 35 feet to 38 feet—40 feet.

Additional anchorages were recommended as follows:—An extension
of the existing River View anchorage 1500 feet x 4500 feet which will double
the size of the existing anchorage, making a new anchorage 1500 feet x 9000
feet. The old portion of this anchorage to be deepened to 38 feet-40 feet,
and the new portion to be dredged to this new deepened depth.

The section of the channel as it exists at the present time, between the
northwesterly end of the existing River View anchorage and Fort McHenry,
1s 1000 feet wide. At Fort McHenry the channel branches with one section
extending northerly into the northwest branch, and the other section ex-
tends westerly to Port Covington.

The Export and Import Bureau has made no request for widening the
northwest channel. This may be because of the location of Fort McHenry
which does not lend itself to commercial or pier development and will for
all time, be held more or less sacred to Baltimoreans and to the country as
a whole, with opposition against dredging operations which might tend to
the possible injury of this historic point. The channel opposite Fort
MecHenry is only 910 feet wide, being limited on the east by the pierhead
line in the vicinity of Lazaretto light. Since it is most unlikely that dredg-
ing operations will be conducted on the west side of this northwest entrance
in the vicinity of Fort McHenry, where no commercial developments are
practicable, the entrance to the northwest branch is limited to its present
910 feet width. TFederal jurisdiction over the channels in this port ends at
this point.

The recent widening and deepening of the C&D Canal has effected mate-
rial changes in the channels leading into Baltimore. In addition to the
improvements listed, as recommended by the Association of Commerce,
the Association also recommended a proposed new short cut channel to
connect Brewerton channel with the natural eastern ship channel of the
